This is the responsibility of DAERA Northern Ireland Environment Agency .”That answer came despite the RHI Inquiry recommending Stormont stopped operating in silos and behaved coherently as a single government entity.However, Kilroot’s owner then told the Belfastit had been meeting the department, NIEA, electricity grid operator SONI and the Utility Regulator to discuss this issue since the crisis began. That was put to the Department for the Economy and to Edwin Poots’ Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, which is responsible for NIEA.But there was no response at the time of going to press.EP Kilroot, a subsidiary of Czech company Energetický, which owns the plant, said it “condemns the indefensible aggression and actions by Russia”.It added that it “complies with all UK sanctions and associated regulations in relation to Russia”, and stressed there were “signicant stock levels of coal on the Kilroot site at present”.It said: “We have contingency plans in place for alternative sources of coal supply. “This plan requires changing EP Kilroot’s permit, which currently prevents us from using coals from other countries.“Since the start of the Ukraine crisis, EP Kilroot has chaired a number of roundtable workshops with officials from DfE, NIEA, the Utility Regulator and SONI to urgently address the issues of the current permitting arrangements to enable EP Kilroot to remove its reliance on Russian coal.“If the permitting arrangements are not changed, we believe there will be signicant security of supply risks that SONI will need to manage.”The company claimed there could also be “signicant additional costs” for consumers “depending on the extent to which the coal units are restricted”.When DfE, headed by DUP minister Gordon Lyons, was asked for its view on whether Kilroot should continue to buy Russian coal, the department expressed no preference, and said: “The purchase of coal is a commercial decision taken by EP Kilroot. However, the department will follow the guidance that has been issued by the UK Government in relation to Russian imports.”When asked how much coal stocks were in place at Kilroot, DfE said “this is not a matter for the department”, but SONI would tell itthere was a problem. When asked how much secondary fuel was stored at Kilroot, DfE said that was a matter for the company.SONI said it was “unaware of any immediate risk to coal stock at Kilroot”. It said inspection of fuel stocks was “not a matter for SONI”. It added Kilroot “has a key role to play in the energy transition”, involving the current generators as well as new gas turbines.Belfast Harbour said it was “working closely with shipping agents and relevant partners to implement all of the Government’s legislative sanctions on Russian vessels”, but it would only bar vessels excluded by law, rather than go further.The Utility Regulator said Kilroot was responsible for ensuring it held adequate fuel stocks. It added: “In light of the ongoing situation in Ukraine, we are working with DfE to proactively monitor the situation, and are engaging with EP Kilroot and other key stakeholders on a regular basis about fuel stocks and fuel security arrangements.”Overall imports of coal have generally been falling, but have risen to the point where they are now roughly where they were in , despite the reduction in the use of coal for home-heating and electricity generation.Irish state-owned electricity company ESB said it will not be taking delivery of Russian coal to its Moneypoint power station in Co Clare “for the foreseeable future”. It was reported that members of staff at the River Shannon facility had expressed concerns to management about accepting Russian coal in the current circumstances.On Monday, Andrei Melnichenko, owner story: Jumping for joy: A reveller enjoying himself on a St Patrick’s Day parade in Belfast city centre. Credit: PacemakerAllan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWith St Patrick’s Day celebrations ing in style across Northern Ireland this week, the Belfasthas everything you need to know on travel arrangements and weather.The Met Office has forecast that Wednesday promises to be a dry day after a misty start to the morning, with sunny periods and light winds to follow.Maximum temperatures are expected to be °C.Read MoreSt Patrick’s Day : Events and activities across Northern Ireland this March Looking ahead to the main event on Thursday, those travelling to celebrations are told to expect bright spells and scattered showers before drier conditions later in the day.Friday and Saturday are forecast to be dry and mild with some good spells of sunshine.With huge numbers expected to attend St Patrick’s Day celebrations across Northern Ireland, Translink will be operating holiday timetables on Thursday, March .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up , Glider and Ulsterbus will operating Saturday and school holiday Translink website by using the Journey Planner feature, or by phoning the Contact Centre for information on    .For the largest event in Belfast, the main celebrations start on Wednesday night with a free St Patrick’s concert taking place in Custom House Square between pm to pm.Belfast City Council have called on drivers to exercise extreme caution when driving in and around the area of Custom House Square, Queen’s Square and Victoria Street due to large volumes of pedestrians attending the event.Those attending should also not there is no designated city centre parking for the evening concert.Drivers are also advised not to park at the SSE Arena on Wednesday night due to the Challenge Cup Final ‘Belfast Giants v Cardf Devils’ taking place.For those wishing to drive, other car parks are available near Custom House Square including the NCP Belfast City Quays Car Park on Donegall Quay.On St Patrick’s day on Thursday, traffic restrictions and ersions will operate in Belfast City Centre during the annual Carnival Parade.Belfast City Council has encouraged those attending any of the events to use public transport.On street parking, including blue badge spaces, will be suspended from am to .pm along Upper Arthur Street, Donegall Place, High Street, Bridge Street and Donegall Street to accommodate the parade and spectators.Drivers can also expect some disruption along the parade route, with rolling ersions in place from .pm to .pm on roads and streets that intersect with the route.The pageant is to leave Belfast City Hall at pm and travel down Donegall Place, turning right into Castle Place, then High Street, left into Bridge Street, Waring Street and finishing on Donegall Street close to Writers Square.There will also be no designated city centre parking for the St Patrick’s carnival parade.Further information on city centre car parks is available here.Elsewhere in the city, drivers should note the SPAR Craic k event will see around , runners leaving Belfast directions of police, any signage and exercise caution along the route.Looking to events in Londonderry, those attending are also encouraged to use public transport where possible and drivers are told to expect some delays and ersions.Bishop Street, Shipquay Street and Strand Road will be restricted to traffic for ying s of time during the afternoon between pm and pm with ersions in place.The Foyle title: unionists hail government u turn over united kingdom to great britain customs switch
story: UUP leader Doug Beattie. Credit: Liam McBurney FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueUUP leader Doug Beattie. Credit: Liam McBurneyStaff ReporterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailUnionists have welcomed a climbdown by the Government over customs regulations that proposed changing all mentions of “the United Kingdom” to “Great Britain” — deliberately omitting Northern Ireland.Sky News reported that Foreign Secretary and UK Brexit negotiator Liz Truss had ordered officials to investigate how the statutory instrumentwas allowed to get to that point without “proper political scrutiny”.In multiple amendments to the The Customs Regulations , it was proposed that instead of using the words “the United Kingdom” that “Great Britain” should be used instead.The Government had presented the amendments as minor and insignicant and would ensure NI-GB trade could “continue smoothly”.The move provoked uproar online, as critics noted that this would directly contradict the Government’s position on the Northern Ireland Protocol by entrenching it further.Ulster Unionist leader Doug Beattie said he thought the initial move was “reprehensible by this Tory Government”.“Why on earth would we trust them, where is the sense in handing power to them ” he asked.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “We must stand our ground and represent the people of Northern Ireland within the Union — not give up for political expediency.”Conservative MP Steve Baker said Article  of the Withdrawal Agreement “makes clear that Northern Ireland is part of the customs territory of the UK. This was a crucial concession from the EU.“I know from my recent trip to Belfast that temperatures are running incredibly high among the unionist community. We cannot forget that the Belfast Agreement operates east-west as well as north-south.“This SI suggests that we are waving the white flag on the NI Protocol.”Northern Irish Labour peer Baroness Hoey tweeted: “Are there any Conservative MPs who care about the Union ”After news of the U-turn filtered through after Ms Truss’ intervention, Mr Beattie tweeted: “Engagement works and must be shown to work.“Without a voice we have no influence, without a voice we cannot outline the problems, without a voice we rely on those who do not have our best interests at heart. Let’s not throw away our voice.”Sky News deputy political editor Sam Coates said what had happened was “raising eyes at the Treasury, whose amendment it was”.Related topicsNI ProtocolDoug BeattieUlster Unionist PartyMore On Credit: Liam McBurney PA WireSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailStormont is on course to waste at least £m — and perhaps as much as £m — over the next  years due to its failure to find a way to spend Treasury funding made available to Northern Ireland for subsidising renewable heat.As revealed by the Belfastlast week, £m has already been wasted in this way and there is no sign of the Department for the Economy producing an alternative proposal for how it can spend the money.However, new figures show the vast scale of the waste aheadthe situation remains unaltered. In response to a Freedom of Information request from the Renewable Heat Association— which represents most RHI claimants — the department said that it was now on course to underspend by around £m. However, those figures only cover expenditure until , yet the GB RHI scheme — from whose budget Northern Ireland’s share of money for renewable heat is derived — has been extended and will not now close until .Based on that longer duration for the GB scheme, RHANI has calculated that Northern Ireland’s underspend may be closer to £m.Read MoreCriticism as Queen’s University Belfast ‘spends over £k’ on Amazon during pandemicThe hidden RHI scandal of how Stormont wasted £m in green energy subsidiesThe department said that it “will explore the potential to utilise any available [Treasury] funds in support of alternative or additional actions to decarbonise heat”. However, there is still no suggestion that this work has reached an advanced stage nor even that it will be possible because the Executive remains unable to decide how to handle existing RHI claimants.Those claimants were promised unalterable payments for  years but once the calamitous scale of the RHI overspend became apparent, Stormont abandoned that promise and retrospectively slashed their payments, meaning the actual overspend was £.m.That decision made them far less well rewarded than their counterparts in Great Britain or the Republic of Ireland, which recently launched its own version of RHI — putting Northern Irish businesses at a competitive disadvantage.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Sources within the DUP suggest that the party is split on how to handle the situation. Former leader Arlene Foster — the minister who set up the disastrous scheme but then said she was “accountable but not responsible” for the mess which followed — had endorsed a policy of throwing all RHI claimants out of the scheme, paying them a fraction of what they were originally promised as compensation. Sinn Fein has also endorsed this policy, but other DUP figures believe it is unfair to those claimants who entered the scheme in good faith, took on huge loans at the suggestion of its minister and government officials, and who did not abuse RHI.There is another factor which might explain the decision not to spend such a vast sum of money. The retrospective cuts to subsidies which had been guaranteed were immediately challenged in court by claimants. However, that process has moved tortoise-like over the last five years and has not yet gone to the Supreme Court. That case is just one of several RHI legal actions, the outcome of which the department cannot be certain.It may be that its decision not to launch a new green heat scheme is a way of hedging against the possibility that the original scheme is reinstated and it faces a vast compensation bill.Whatever the reason, it is having an increasingly stark impact. As oil and gas prices soar, renewables are among the cheapest alternatives — but have high up-front costs to install, which is why subsidies are in place where across the UK and Ireland.RHANI executive chairman Andrew Trimble said: “If civil servants had not removed  words from the national legislation on renewable heat when the NI legislation was implemented, then today we would have a strong, sustainable, environmentally friendly renewable heat sector. We would be contributing to our pathway to net zero and have a vastly reduced reliance on fossil fuels — with their polluting emissions reduced by %.”He said that Stormont could solve the problem by reinstating the missing  words — essentially replicating the GB scheme, with cost controls, something he said “could solve the political problems that Stormont and the department have created for themselves and for the people of Northern Ireland”.Mr Trimble highlighted that in , a Commons committee inquiry branded the department’s actions “a raw deal”, but the department had repeatedly failed to help genuine claimants suffering as a result of their broken promises.Related topicsDepartment for the EconomyThe Executive OfficeArlene FosterSinn FéinClimate ChangeMore On Department for the title: corrie mckeague inquest detective suspicious of reset of bin weights device
story: Missing RAF serviceman Corrie McKeague at around .am on September ,   FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMissing RAF serviceman Corrie McKeague at around .am on September ,  By Sam Russell, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA device used to record bin weights on the bin lorry that visited the area where RAF gunner Corrie McKeague was last seen was ed to factory settings the day before it was collected by police, an inquest heard.The airman, of Dunfermline, Fe, was  when he disappeared in the early hours of September ,  after a night out in Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk.He was last seen on CCTV at .am entering a service area behind a Greggs store and police believe he climbed into a bin which was then tipped into a waste lorry."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_dfccf--aa-aa-ced_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_dfccf--aa-aa-ced_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_dfccf--aa-aa-ced_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_dfccf--aa-aa-ced_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "RAF gunner Corrie McKeague, who vanished on a night out in  PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRAF gunner Corrie McKeague, who vanished on a night out in  Waste firm Bfa initially told police that the weight of the bin was kgbut it was later recorded as kg .Detective Constable Richard Morgan told an inquest in Ipswich that an electronic device, kept in the cab of the bin lorry and used by the driver for bin weights, was ed to factory settings the day before it was collected by police, on February , .Data from the device is downloaded to the database of waste firm Bfa after a lorry completes its rounds.I thought it was highly suspicious. It was quite clear why I wanted it. By wiping it, it put that data beyond useDet Con MorganLawyer Dr Anton van Dellen, asking questions on behalf of Mr McKeague’s father Martin McKeague, said: “Concentrating on that wiping of the , as a detective constable in a major investigation team, you’re going round collecting evidence for an investigation.“You’ve found that somebody has effectively wiped theof electronic information that as far as you’re aware they’re fully aware you wanted to look at.“What view,any, did you take about how suspicious that action was ”Det Con Morgan replied: “I thought it was highly suspicious.“It was quite clear why I wanted it.“By wiping it, it put that data beyond use.“Someone at the Bfa depot did this.”He added that police later learned that the data stored on the device would have been of “no evidential value to us” anyway, adding that it was “ludicrous” that somebody had performed a hard reset.The correct bin weight, of kg, was provided by senior staff at Bfa who got the firm’s IT experts to examine raw data in the database.The inquest heard that bin lorry driver Martyn Thompson was first spoken to by police on September , and the following day changes were made to Bfa’s front-end facing IT system Bfanet so users would see the weight as kg.This did not alter the weights in the database underpinning it, which could not be seen by users of Bfanet.Det Con Morgan said two staff from the Bfa depot in Bury St Edmunds, who were not named, were interviewed under caution on suspicion of perverting the course of justice and were later told they faced no further action.Bin lorry driver Mr Thompson was never a suspect in the investigation.Det Con Morgan said that one of the iniduals said when interviewed that Mr Thompson had asked for “reassurance” about the bin weight.“When I interviewed one of the iniduals, what they said was hewas having self-doubt about whether the bin was heavy enough,” said Det Con Morgan.“He wanted reassurance the bin wasn’t heavy enough and he was given that reassurance.”Mr Thompson earlier told the inquest he checked the bin and did not see anybody inside it.The inquest previously heard that the time taken for the bin lorry to enter and leave the service area was  seconds.Det Con Morgan said that in  officers filmed the bin lting process on the lorry and recorded that it took  seconds from the bin being attached to the lorry to it being tipped and ed to the ground.The inquest, being heard with a jury, continues.
